did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia financial and legal records

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of financial records of the Library Company of Philadelphia. These materials document the financial operations of the institution and significant trusts and estates bequeathed to it. Items include: account books, ledgers, investments, cash receipts and disbursements, and petty cash vouchers; printed audit reports and financial statements (1936-1991); treasurer's and bank committee reports; director's expenses; librarian's accounts; records of book orders (1880s-1928); canceled checks and checkbooks (1847-1882); tax receipts (1879-1926); and correspondence, receipts, and statements related to the 1964-65 Building Fund. Trust and estate materials include: correspondence, wills, deeds, inventories, and accounts of the Rush estate; accounts, wills, and inventories of the James Logan estate; records of properties owned by the Library Company, including rent books, land surveys, records of settlement, correspondence, and deeds. The collection also includes material related to legal cases involving the Library Company, including a lawsuit between the Library Company and Henry J. Williams, executor of the Rush estate.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
